TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose Senator Chamarette's impractical and counterproductive motion. I say at the outset that, with all the best will in the world, with an absolutely massive drafting effort—the like of which we have never seen before—the logistical constraints and the timetable which would be imposed by Senator Chamarette's motion cannot be met. A significant amount of budget legislation simply cannot be drafted by 1 October. That is partly due to the limited drafting resources that exist, and partly due to the time available to refine the details of new policies which were announced in the budget. Of course, that time will be curtailed. The same goes for some other legislation. This is not to mention urgent and unforeseen legislation that comes in to the parliament—something that occurs in every session, as all senators know. There is not a lot of legislation in that category but there is always some.

PARA.TAB: I also say that the quality of the legislation that comes before the parliament would suffer if this motion were agreed to by the Senate. Mistakes in bills which otherwise would be picked up in time would be overlooked because of inadequate time for checking. Bills would not be as well written as otherwise they might be, and time would be lost in making the consequential amendments. This proposal, if agreed to, would be counterproductive in terms of time. Also the fundamental principle must be stressed that this proposal would be seen as nothing more or less than an interference by this chamber in the business and the conduct of the House of Representatives. It would be a very significant and unnecessary irritant in relations between the two chambers.

Senator Chamarette is making a most extraordinary demand—namely, that all legislation must be into the House of Representatives by 1 October and out by 29 October. It is absolutely inappropriate for a so-called house of review to impose those sorts of constraints on the business of the house of government. I know that some in this chamber, such as the Australian Democrats, have recognised that.

The conditions which Senator Chamarette wants to attach to the exceptions to this cut-off procedure are also completely unacceptable. Senator Chamarette would probably accept that the only reason those conditions appear is that I have raised with her for a very long time the issue of budget and urgent bills. The proposal for a time-wasting procedural debate, which is put forward in her motion, will on every occasion bog this chamber down in more procedural guff than we have even at this time.

I accept that Senator Chamarette is not motivated by ill will in moving this motion. However, I believe—I have said it to her directly, and I will say it publicly today—that this proposition is extraordinarily naive. I do not believe that she genuinely fully understands the ramifications of these proposals.

However, I believe that the opposition does understand the ramifications of these proposals. It particularly understood the ramifications of a cut-off motion, a Macklin motion, at the end of the budget session in 1992 when it thought it would win the next election, so it decided it would not have any constraints placed upon it. That just shows the utter hypocrisy of the position that the Liberal Party is putting up in this debate.

Frankly, last year's cut-off was just a doddle compared with this one. But the opposition opposed it then. Where is its consistency? Where is its principle? That was done at a time the opposition thought it had some prospects of becoming government. Now it examines every single issue before this chamber from the perspective of being Her Majesty's loyal and perpetual opposition. Opposition members know that they are stuck over there for time immemorial, and they are acting accordingly. At some time the opposition may get a bit of leadership in its ranks and approach some of these issues seriously from the point of view of an alternative government.

The government has seriously looked at what it can do in response to the problems that allegedly exist with its legislative program. We have approached these problems with an open mind and have made a very genuine effort to deal with the legislative log jam that people identify as the cause of this motion. A lot of that legislative log jam would not occur if we did not have the time wasting and filibustering by the opposition that has occurred continually in this chamber. If the opposition stopped wasting so much time in the Senate on matters of little relevance, we all could get on to the real task at hand.

I think it is fair to say that the government has already taken some very significant steps to circulate information about the legislative program well in advance of the budget sittings. The non-budget legislation program for the budget sittings was circulated by me, as Manager of Government Business, on 26 July. To be fair to Senator Hill, I think he made some positive comment about that in his contribution, and that was appreciated. I think that indicates the government's goodwill in this matter.

The programming has been handled on a cooperative basis in the past. There has been full consultation between me, as Manager of Government Business, other responsible opposition office holders and the whips, as Senator Burns and Senator Foreman, who are in the chamber, understand. I hope and I expect that that level of cooperation can continue into the future.

The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) made some throwaway line about the fact that the government's proposals and the amendment circulated in the name of Senator Kernot on behalf of the Australian Democrats bore some similarity. He thought there was a conspiracy afoot.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said it was a coincidence.

—Well, a coincidence or a conspiracy. I believe the Democrats have made a genuine effort to come forward with some constructive and worthwhile suggestions in this debate, and the government has responded to them. Hence, it is true that the paper distributed by Senator Gareth Evans has as its genesis the package of Senate reforms that was put forward by the Australian Democrats. The government has tried to meet some of those proposals. They were put forward in a positive way and I think from a genuine position of trying to see some reform in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: What the government has done is to put forward its own, what I believe can fairly be described as, honourable compromise with all the proposals that have been put forward. The government has been able to give an assurance that it will have at least half of its `essential for passage' legislation in by 21 October and the rest introduced by 18 November. They are timetabling constraints set by the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that an l-a-w promise?

—I assume that Senator Kernot will say in this debate—and of course she will speak for herself—`It's not enough for you to give us this assurance. I want it in black and white. I want an amendment carried before the parliament'. We are yet to hear her contribution, but I assume that is what she will say.

PARA.TAB: The government has gone further than that and has indicated that it can give a best endeavours undertaking to program legislation for debate and passage in this form. These are constraints that fundamentally were raised with the government by the Greens. The best endeavours proposal is to have one-third of the bills proposed for passage this session dealt with by 1 October, a further one-third of such bills dealt with by 18 November, and the last one-third dealt with in the remainder of the scheduled sitting period, which is by 16 December.

Having had those suggestions put to us by the minor parties and Independents, the government is saying, again in good faith and I believe with an open mind, that we will go further than that and we will work towards meeting the objective of introduction in one sittings and debate the next. Obviously, exceptions will have to be made for budget, urgent or unforeseen legislation, as all honourable senators would understand.

The government has also agreed—so has the Senate today—to send off to the Procedure Committee the question of rationalising the hours and days of sitting, times of sitting and the question of the proposed changes to the order of business that have been suggested by the Australian Democrats. We have done that in such a way—for those who care to examine the motion that was agreed to this morning—which will allow all parties, including the minor parties and Independents, to get involved in looking at those options for change. I believe that they are constructive and worthwhile proposals. The government wants to see them progressed. It wants to see some genuine change and some reform. We will be approaching the proposals that were made with a very open mind indeed.

One of the other issues that was raised by the Australian Democrats related to the budget being brought forward. That announcement has already been made and it will require some change to the pattern of sittings. We have also been able to make commitments about the forward program of legislation and its being circulated at least three weeks before sittings. As well as that, we have been able to offer all parties and all Independents briefings on all legislation that comes before this chamber. As I say, that is a very honourable compromise to a range of suggestions that were put to the government—an appropriate response not only to Senator Chamarette's motion but also to the suggestions that were made by the Australian Democrats.

I said before that I believe that Senator Chamarette has been operating in good faith. I believe it happens to be misguided good faith; nevertheless, she is not approaching this from a position of ill will. I do not suggest for one minute that the same is true of the opposition. Frankly, that sleazy and opportunistic bunch on the other side of the chamber are experienced enough to know exactly what they are doing and what impact it has on the processes of good government. Of course, those opposite are unprincipled enough not to care about it because they know the situation that they find themselves in in Australian politics. This proposal from Senator Chamarette could never be embraced by a government.

I have said this before and I stand by it: it is a constitutional impertinence, a constitutional affront, for the Senate to dictate to the House of Representatives its own procedures. No government can accept that. The opposition claims to respect the Senate and claims that its processes are vital to Australian democracy. But by supporting this motion the opposition is just setting out to destroy that sort of role.

I have only been in the Senate a pretty short time—four years—but I have heard such an amount of sanctimonious, sickening, claptrap from the opposition about the role it plays as a house of review. Now, all of a sudden, it is all a movable feast. We are now told that the Senate can reserve the right to say exactly what it will review. If this motion gets up, we are really saying that we can dictate to the House of Representatives, the people's house, what legislation it will deal with and what legislation will pass through the parliament. I have to say that it is simply not on for the Senate to make those demands of the House of Representatives. No serious government, and no serious alternative government, could ever embrace such a proposition.

We have introduced new procedures and deadlines to ensure that legislation is ready for introduction much earlier than in the past. We have indicated that we can be confident that we can have half in by 21 October and the rest by 18 November. We can give an absolute assurance on that. We have endorsed the principle of introduction in one sittings and passage or debate the next. We will be working towards achieving that for non-budget legislation over the next few sittings.

As we move closer to that goal, an increasing proportion of legislation will be available not weeks but literally months before it is debated. We have introduced the practice of circulating well in advance of sittings a global legislation program, which includes a brief description of each bill. That is in addition to the usual forward program. Of course, such a program was circulated for these sittings on 23 July.

Also, in order to assist honourable senators in their scrutiny of legislation, we have undertaken to make briefings available on all bills. I, as Manager of Government Business, and the Leader of the House have written to all parties and Independents about that. That is being considered by honourable senators. As I said, there will soon be a serious examination in the Procedure Committee on those other elements of the Democrats' reform package. This motion is not only a constitutional impertinence; it is arrogant, arbitrary, impractical and absolutely unacceptable to the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —To borrow a line from somebody else and vary it: oh to be in the Senate now that the numbers are here. We all understand the reasons why Senator Chamarette has moved this motion. She produced tables and she used her own set of statistics; I could do the same. But they simply prove what we all know and have experienced—that the Senate has not been particularly well managed in the past. That is the starting point; the government has acknowledged that. We then need to make a sensible vote in the interests of the Senate.
—You believe them?
—I do believe it. I am not so cynical as to disbelieve everything that the government says.
—The electorate believed them last election.

—Yes, and the electors did not believe the opposition. We all want to avoid the end of year log jam; that is taken as read. But should we then vote for a motion which imposes a 1 October cut-off date? I think we have to be reasonable people. PARA.TAB: The second problem that I have relates to part (3) of the motion. Part (3) sets up golden opportunities for hijacking and obstructionism. The problem with this motion—and it is probably unintended—is that it will be up to the Senate to debate every request that is made to classify a bill as being urgent or arising out of a budget statement. That is what can happen in the Senate when we do not have people of goodwill prepared to use this chamber for constructive purposes. I really do not want to give the opposition an opportunity to use a loophole to exploit the processes of this chamber. That is one of the big problems I have with Senator Chamarette's motion.

The other problem I have is the inconsistency/hypocrisy of the opposition. Last year it denied the Australian Democrats the right to move what is called `the Macklin cut-off motion'. It was not the right thing to do then; suddenly, this year, a whole new range of principles apply, one being that the opposition is not about to be elected to government.

I think it is important that we look at the parts of the Senate reform proposals that the Democrats have put forward. I am pleased that some of the components of those proposals have been sent off to the Standing Committee on Procedure for consideration. I invite everyone to make submissions to that procedure committee. I especially invite Senator Herron, who is the occupational health watchdog for all of us in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of them.

—One of them, yes. He has strong feelings about this. We must take this opportunity to bring about saner working conditions for all of us here. So I really implore people: do not just whinge about it in the lobby; actually say something about it to the Procedure Committee. Let us look at more logical, sensible and humanly achievable ways of working in this chamber. I now formally move the amendment circulated in my name. I move:

PARA.TAB: Delete all words after `that' and replace them with—

3.That when a bill

PARA.TAB: (a)is introduced in the Senate by a Minister after 18 November 1993, or

4.That, immediately after debate on a motion for the second reading of a bill is adjourned in accordance with paragraph 2 or 3 or following the giving of notices on a subsequent day, a motion may be moved without notice to refer that bill to a standing committee for inquiry and report by a day not later than the first day of sitting in 1994.

The purpose of this amendment is to move from the in principle guarantee, which I was perfectly happy to accept from Senator Gareth Evans but which, it seems, other people want in black and white. The government is willing to accommodate that request. In part 1 of my amendment I am saying this: the government has an obligation to spell out up front its programs, its new initiatives, the names of the bills and a summary of the details of the bills. This is something that it has not had to do before but which it is now willing to do. The details are important. This is where we can have the scrutiny that Senator Chamarette and Senator Harradine refer to.

PARA.TAB: In part 2 of my amendment I say to the government: if you do not meet our requirement of having half of the bills introduced into the parliament by 21 October, you suffer the consequences of having all the rest of those bills deferred to next year. I think that is a huge sanction and a huge challenge for the government to meet; it is willing to meet it.

In part 3 of my amendment I say to the government: if you meet the challenge of part 2, the second half of your bills must be introduced by 18 November. So this forces a two-stage process of introduction. The government, in its best endeavours, has gone further than that and has said that it will introduce legislation on an introduce-one-session debate-the-next basis, to the extent that this proves possible. This is something we have not had before either. Again, here is an opportunity for scrutiny, deliberation and further briefings, where necessary.

Part 4 of my amendment simply follows the same suggestion as Senator Chamarette's motion: it is a standard part which does not prevent committee inquiries. Parts 5 and 6 of my amendment are standard as well.

We need to come back now to some of the points that have been made so far in the debate. I am glad that Senator Faulkner set the record straight, for Senator Alston's sake. The government's proposals have been put forward. The 50:50 share and cut-off dates have been proposed by the Democrats and the government has shown that it is willing to meet those deadlines and that challenge.

To go back to Senator Chamarette's motion, people have talked about the power of the double deadline. I think the real disadvantage of the double deadline would be that corners would be cut. We would have perhaps shoddier legislation than we already have in this chamber. In terms of efficiency, the real time is lost afterwards when we have to spend so much time fixing up the problems of legislation introduced under a guillotine, rushed up here, often having to be amended, with 25 government amendments to one bill.

The Democrats' motion, contrary to what has been asserted by the opposition, does not repeat the Macklin cut-off. It goes much further. Let me say again that it requires a full list of the bills and summaries to be dealt with this session to be tabled less than two weeks from now. That is a massive improvement on what we have had in the past. The motion requires half of those bills to be in the parliament by 21 October and the rest before 18 November. It requires much earlier introduction and therefore gives us much greater time for scrutiny.

I think it is sensible to marry the government's undertaking with the sanctions and the workable nature of the Democrats' motion, and add to that the matters which have gone off to the Procedure Committee for report back by the end of September. Hopefully, at the end of this year, if we were all prepared to examine these with our conscience and with goodwill, we would have a reformed Senate, a much better place for debate, and a much better place for us to work in. That is my hope, and that was my intention in moving for a wider range of Senate reform proposals. I commend my amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this debate has been a good one. It has enabled Senator Chamarette in particular to detail her proposal to the chamber and it has enabled Senator Faulkner to indicate to the Senate the government's objection to that proposal. It has also enabled Senator Kernot to make a most constructive contribution to the debate.

PARA.TAB: There have been certain statements made here which are political in nature—not that much that is said here is not of that nature. I am really talking about the statement by Senator Faulkner that Senator Chamarette's motion is constitutionally impertinent. I do not quite know what Senator Faulkner means by that, but I would have thought that one of the greatest of impertinences has been the way the government has treated this chamber over a period in respect of its duties to review legislation. It has not given us proper opportunities to exercise that function in respect of a number of important pieces of legislation over recent years. That is the impertinence. It has been acknowledged all round the chamber, I believe, that that sort of interference—indirect interference, if you like—cannot continue.

I would have been very interested to hear a logical, consistent and compelling case put by a member of the House of Representatives, or someone on his or her behalf in this chamber, as to how we would be interfering with the House of Representatives if we passed Senator Chamarette's motion. In my view, there has been no such compelling argument.

I see the problem in two parts: one is an individual problem and the other is a collective problem. The individual problem we have with legislation that comes before us is that we do not have sufficient time, in many instances, to know the principles behind the legislation and the details of that legislation before we debate it in this chamber. Therefore, the scrutiny of that legislation is inadequate. The ability for members of the public to make their representations to us on the legislation is inadequate.

I asked the government—and it has been rejected—why the instructions delivered by the instructing departments to the Office of Parliamentary Counsel cannot be tabled in the Senate and in the House of Representatives when they are received by the OPC. What is wrong with that? We would then have advance notice of what the legislation is intended to do. We would have detailed instructions by the instructing department about what the bill should contain. Why should we not be entitled to the first draft from the OPC? Why should that not be tabled in both houses of parliament? I indicated that, if that were to be the case, standing orders should be amended to prohibit debate at that stage. There is a standing order which, as honourable senators know, prohibits debate in anticipation of a matter that is currently on the Notice Paper, but that would not be sufficient. We would have to amend standing orders to ensure that there were not two bites at the cherry, as it were.

To my way of thinking, that would give not only members of the Senate but also members of the House of Representatives a fairer opportunity to examine what the bills would most likely contain and therefore to address their minds to it well before the bills came into either of the houses. I am not talking about confidential cabinet material. We are assuming that cabinet has made its decision. We are assuming that the minister concerned has made the public announcement. We are assuming that the instructing department has then issued detailed instructions to the OPC. Why can we not get hold of those detailed instructions?

A suggestion has been made to me that it might be embarrassing. I have one thing in mind. I give honourable senators an example, and I think many will understand what I am saying. The suggestion of amendments to the Industrial Relations Act has been around for some time. A decision has been made by cabinet; an announcement has been made by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton. For example, enterprise agreements are proposed to be permitted under the Industrial Relations Act which do not require the approval of a union. As I understand it, Mr Brereton has guaranteed the ACTU that the provisions of such enterprise agreements shall not contain terms and conditions less than the terms and conditions of the relevant federal award. This is because a number of people were, quite justifiably, concerned that these enterprise agreements would be used to undercut the hard-fought terms and conditions of federal awards.

I would like to see what the instructing department has done with that policy and what it has said to the OPC about that. Why should we not know that? This is not a secret society—or it should not be a secret society. This is a government decision taken by cabinet and announced by the minister. There is no secret about it. Why should we not be permitted to have the instructions of the instructing department when they are received by the OPC? As well, why should we not have the first draft of the bill when the OPC has dealt with the instructions?

It has been suggested that there could be an embarrassment in all of this, as very often changes are made because the OPC has said, `You cannot do it this way; you have to do it that way'. So what? That is part of life. We are mature members of parliament—or we should be. These sorts of processes can be helped by us and by the public. After having a look at the draft legislation, the public would be able to say, `I do not think this quite meets the government's intention when it made its decision'. But the government says we are not entitled to that. For the government's information, we could be entitled to it if the Senate adopted a motion for an order for its return. At some stage in some of these matters we ought to look at that. Through a motion we ought to order a particular instructing department to return the drafting instructions on certain legislation for tabling in this parliament.

But this is beside the point. For the purposes of this exercise, and for the purpose of giving us desperately needed advance information, the government is not going to go along with that. What it is prepared to do is contained in the undertaking given by Senator Evans and in the amendment moved by Senator Kernot:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.That there be laid on the Table of the Senate, not later than 6 pm on Monday, 30 August 1993, by the Leader of the Government in the Senate:

PARA.TAB: (a)a list indicating those bills which the Leader of the Government in the Senate declares are bills which it is intended that the Senate pass during the budget sittings 1993; and
(b)for each such bill, a summary of its contents.

SPEECH.PARA: I have seen such summaries of contents. The summaries of contents that we sometimes see relating to legislation are pretty pathetic and do not give us much to properly examine in detail.

PARA.TAB: So in that sense the amendment moved by Senator Kernot does not fill the bill so far as I am concerned. I suppose it could be suggested that nor does the motion of Senator Chamarette. How can we consult the persons who are likely to be affected by that legislation, and thus give them the opportunity to give us information, so that we can represent their views in this chamber?

Senator Evans focused on paragraph (3) of Senator Chamarette's motion. He seemed to be indicating that paragraph (3) has the potential to bog down the Senate in debate on these issues. Paragraph (3) states:

SPEECH.PARA: This order—
that is, the order relating to when the Senate will debate bills, et cetera—
may be suspended by motion on notice, subject to the time limits on debate on motions to suspend standing and other orders, in relation to bills arising from the budget statements or urgent bills.

I do not know whether Senator Evans has cottoned on to the implications of standing order 142. Standing order 142 deals with the meaning of urgent bills. If I were Senator Evans, I might have grabbed this with both hands. I see some confusion between this proposal, were it incorporated into the standing orders, and standing order 142. Standing order 142 deals with urgent bills and is entitled, `Limitation of debate on bills'. It states:

(1) When a motion for leave to introduce a bill is called on, or when a message is received from the House of Representatives transmitting a bill for concurrence, or at any other stage of a bill, a Minister may declare that the bill is an urgent bill, and move that the bill be considered an urgent bill, and such motion shall be put forthwith without debate or amendment.

As you know, this is a time limitation on urgent bills. If paragraph (3) of Senator Chamarette's motion is limited to urgent bills, then the way is opened up for ministers to declare that certain bills are urgent bills and then to move for limitation of debate on those urgent bills. Yet Senator Evans has come in here and said that paragraph (3)—

Even by 1996-97, when the full effect of these tax changes will be in place, the burden on the Australian taxpayer, measured as a percentage of GDP, will be only 24.3 per cent, and that is substantially less than the burden upon the taxpaying public that was the case right through the 1980s. Let us hear no more of this particular furphy. What we have done in this budget is totally consistent with what was said right throughout the period leading up to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister's answer was somewhat astonishing, when one looks at the increases in personal tax of $957 million and indirect tax of $230 million. Apart from that, my real question, to which I still have not received an answer, was whether the minister is disputing that on 19 November 1992 the Prime Minister said, `What I am promising is not to put up tax'. If he is not disputing that, why can the Prime Minister be so dishonest and get away with it?

—What the Prime Minister was promising, what the Treasurer has promised, what others in the government have promised, and what I am repeating now, is a repetition of a statement that we would not increase the tax burden. Those statements occurred in the context of our attitude towards the GST and the spectacular contrast between the government and the opposition as it was then and as it will remain in the future.

PARA.TAB: We promised not to introduce a GST. We have not introduced a GST. We promised not to broaden the tax base. We have not broadened the tax base. We promised to increase tax cuts. We are implementing tax cuts on the income tax side. We promised overall not to increase the burden, and we have not overall increased the burden.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Colston, I remind honourable senators that it is not parliamentary to say that the Prime Minister was dishonest.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Look at all the precedents that have been set for a long time before me.

—I direct my question to the minister representing the Attorney-General. Can the minister advise what progress, if any, was made at the latest meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in relation to a transfer to Australia of Australian citizens who are held in overseas prisons? Can the minister also advise whether there are any prospects of a transfer treaty being negotiated with Thailand, which holds a greater number of Australian prisoners than any other foreign country?

—The last meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General was held in June this year and unfortunately not all jurisdictions were able to give a final indication as to whether they wanted to participate in an international prisoner transfer scheme. As a result, Australia's participation in such a scheme is still to be settled. The states and territories are important because returning prisoners do need to be held in prisons in the state or territory with which they are connected. Despite the fact that agreement has not been reached, the Commonwealth's position still is to favour, in principle, a transfer of prisoners by way of such a scheme. We remain committed to that, and the idea remains on the agenda to be discussed by attorneys-general in November this year.

PARA.TAB: If the proposal does go ahead, however, in terms of where we would start with the rest of the world, the first step would be to seek to become a party to the Council of Europe convention on the transfer of sentenced persons. As well as that, there is a Commonwealth scheme that we would seek to participate in. This does not cover Senator Colston's concern with the transfer of prisoners from Thailand. We would treat Thailand as we would any other country; we would try to enter into bilateral agreements with it. Thailand is particularly important, as Senator Colston has said, because Thailand is the country where the largest number of Australians are currently serving terms of imprisonment. As at 6 June some 27 Australians were in prison in Thailand.

We could not get agreement on this matter at the last meeting of state and federal attorneys-general. It is up for discussion in November. I ask the Senate to note that even were we to get agreement in the next few months, it would still be two or three years before one would be able to put into place the international bilateral and multilateral treaties that would give effect to any such scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of one of our former colleagues, a distinguished senator from Tasmania, Ray Devlin.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I hope that he will attempt to give a more honest answer to me than that which he gave to Senator Hill. I refer Senator Evans to the three claims that the Treasurer made at the conclusion of his budget speech last night; namely, a path leading to an Australia which saves more, a path leading to an Australia which can invest more in its own undoubted strengths, and a path leading crucially to more jobs for our people. As the budget reveals a significant fall in household savings, no improvement in business investment and a token fall in the unemployment rate solely associated with a drop in job seekers, with no fall in the number of unemployed, why do the Treasurer and the government persist in telling the electorate lies? When will the government take action to achieve the three key objectives the Treasurer identified but failed completely to address?

—There is no doubt whatsoever that government policy as spelt out in the budget will contribute very dramatically to the achievement of those three objectives. Let me explain why. The first thing the budget does is inject a fiscal stimulus into the economy—a modest one, measured of the order of about $2 billion, but significant nonetheless and one that is clearly needed in the present environment where the job market is, as we all know, still flat and likely to remain so for as long as international full-scale economic recovery is denied us. But there will be that degree of stimulus and that is important.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, it is a part of a very responsible total economic strategy—one that does not just consist of the budget itself, but also of a wages policy, a monetary policy, a micro-economic industry policy and, of course, an employment and training dimension to that policy designed to improve our skill base and assist unemployed people to haul themselves back into a job market that is changing quite dramatically in its characteristics.

Thirdly, the budget itself is a totally responsible one. In the context of a number of criticisms that are being directed at it from particular sources, I think it is important to acknowledge that not one single economic commentator that I have seen has described it as other than a responsible budget, measured in economic terms, in terms of creating a long-term environment of business confidence, overseas investor confidence and overseas financial market confidence.

The reason it has been so characterised and deserves to be so characterised is, firstly, that it is a responsible budget. It does show how the medium-term fiscal target for 1996-97 is going to be achieved. We have got that current stimulus being injected into the economy. Nonetheless, it is not just an open-ended stimulus; it is part of a total strategy designed to bring the budget back into balance in four years time by a pathway that is clearly defined.

Secondly, it is a budget in which all the election commitments which have been honoured in it—131 of them are documented in that particular booklet that was circulated last night—are being funded not by revenue increases but by other reductions in outlay. It is a totally responsible budget from that point of view.

The total budget strategy, when looked at as a whole, is dedicated to the objective of maintaining the low inflation, low interest rate environment which has been our most critical achievement by a very considerable margin—an inflation rate environment which is the best we have had in this country for 30 years and an interest rate environment which is the best we have had in this country for 20 years.

The budget strategy is designed to maintain that environment and there is no better way of getting the investment we need, getting the job growth we need, getting the savings we need than being able to achieve and maintain that particular climate that I have just described. That is why it is a responsible budget, and that is why the opposition has been left without a feather to fly with in trying to attack it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Talking about feathers to fly with, I think the minister just let his blow off.
—Order! Just ask the supplementary.

—Let me ask the minister yet again. Is it a fact that the budget forecasts a fall in household savings? Is it a fact that it forecasts virtually no improvement in business investment? Is it a fact that it predicts no fall in the number of unemployed? Is it also a fact that it forecasts a significant increase in the inflation rate as a result of the direct policies of the budget, and therefore an increase in interest rates and a fall in savings? If those facts are not correct, could the minister point me to where in the budget I am wrong?

—So far as the savings side of the budget is concerned, the strategy I referred to and which the Treasurer emphasised of restoring the budget deficit to around one per cent of GDP by 1996-97 is of course itself a crucial contributor to achieving those savings targets. That will significantly boost the public sector's contribution to national savings. If Senator Short does not understand that, then he is in the wrong job as opposition spokesman.

PARA.TAB: To have attempted, as I have said, a larger fiscal adjustment in the course of just one year would have jeopardised the recovery. That is why no major step forward is taken towards the achievement of that this year. That is why it is deliberately still stimulatory this year, but the overall target is exactly as I have described it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why has the deficit gone up then, Gareth?

—I have described what we are trying to achieve and the reasons we are trying to achieve it. It is crucial to the longer term balance and stability of the economy. In terms of the public sector contribution, you cannot have it both ways. You cannot have the stimulus you need to deal with the continued aftermaths of a recession but at the same time contribute to increased savings. In the longer term you have both—
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Trade, refers to the government's commitment to boosting Australia's international competitiveness and making Australia one of the leading export economies of the world. Can the minister inform the Senate how the budget will assist Australia's emerging exporters?

—As Senator Evans has just said, this is a balanced and responsible budget. One of the most vital features of it is the emphasis it gives to encouraging Australian exporters, in particular the emerging exporters that have been identified in the McKinsey review.

PARA.TAB: Australia exports now about one-fifth of all it produces. Our objective is to lift that percentage of GDP even higher and put this country in the front rank of major exporting economies in the world. A pleasing feature of our current export performance is the massive growth in manufacturing exports, particularly in the exports of elaborately transformed manufactures and in the growth of services exports out of this country. The market area for most of that growth has been East Asia.

We now have seven of our top 10 markets in East Asia. In the early 1970s we had only two of them there; seven of the 10 are there now. In the last five years, particularly in elaborately transformed manufactured goods, we have increased our exports to the North East Asian region by 23 per cent and to South East Asia by 27 per cent. So we have seen a magnificent growth in the export of manufactured goods which as a category now ranks equal to that of agricultural exports out of this country.

Against that background, the McKinsey-AMC study found that the emergent exporters, the small to medium companies in this country that are doing well, have managed to double their export earnings since 1986-87. They now earn—there are some 700 of them—at least in terms of this study, $8 billion in export earnings. That was an important finding, added to the fact that in the next five years they expect to double that $8 billion.

The other significant finding is that there are 6,000 other companies in the manufacturing sector in Australia that also could export their product and earn significant export dollars for this country. How to energise them and encourage them to participate in exporting is a major question for the government and a major finding of the McKinsey report. We have now put in place a series of incentives to help and assist them to meet the particular strategic requirements of these companies and get into the export area—most importantly into East Asia where the economic growth for that region, if you leave out Japan, for this calendar year is about 8 per cent and where there is real demand for the types of goods that we export.

The budget in dealing with this issue, and on behalf of my department and the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development, outlined a series of initiatives valued at $94 million over the next three years. They are: to increase the funding for the international trade enhancement scheme and to make it available to smaller companies; to improve the availability of the export market development grants scheme and to reduce the burden on smaller companies that might be recipients of that scheme; to engage in a `Market Australia' campaign, which is a campaign to sell the image of this country abroad so that we are seen as a source of sophisticated manufactured goods and high-quality services; to establish a task force on market penetration to work out how better we can harmonise our effort in this country to succeed in foreign markets; to establish a national exporter education centre to provide the necessary education backup for our entrepreneurs to succeed in markets in which the prevailing cultural mores are not those of an Anglo-Saxon background; and to increase funding to the Development Import Finance Facility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will conclude at that point. This is a major feature of the budget and one I am sure there is bipartisan support for.
—Order! The chair will call time.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. When the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, claimed victory after the 13 March election he said that it was a victory for the true believers. What does the Minister think the true believers feel about this government's total lack of direct action in terms of job creation—not more and more training but job creation—for Australia's 900,000 unemployed? What does he think the true believers feel about a Labor government handing down a budget which, because of massive petrol and sales tax hikes and completely inadequate compensation, will make lower income earners worse off?

—So far as the question of job growth is concerned, I think I have already answered that. The only way we can generate jobs on a sustainable basis in this country is through a total economic strategy which touches all these bases—fiscal, monetary, wages policy, enterprise bargaining, productivity and the like, a continuation of micro-economic reform plus the skill base increase training programs that are part of that total picture.

PARA.TAB: There is no point in thinking that we can generate major increases in employment or significantly reduce unemployment through specific big spend-up job creation programs of the kind that we have had in the past. It is the case that a significant increase in spending on public infrastructure of the kind that was contained in the One Nation program, for example, elements of which are continued through in this present budget as part of the total stimulus I referred to earlier, can make a contribution.

But the only sustainable way we can really get job growth in this country of the kind that we all need is by getting total growth up over the four per cent mark, which is the kind of thing this strategy is designed to achieve over the shortest possible time frame but which, of course, is significantly dependent on international conditions for its achievement. We hope that a lot of that job growth is going to come from our own region as a result of increased exports. What my colleague Senator Cook has just said about the particular elements in the program that are designed to stimulate exports into that huge new market alongside us is, of course, also directly relevant to the task of creating jobs. That is a key theme in the budget which should not be underestimated.

As to the question of the social equity of the budget, I think it is the case that this budget has to be seen in the context of the government's overall record. Over the past 10 years the priority has been to assist low income people and families. That is why all our previous tax cuts were directed to low income earners. Honourable senators will remember that we previously raised the tax free threshold to $5,400. We previously lowered tax rates to 20 per cent for income up to $20,700. We also increased the family allowance supplement for low income families. We have increased this in real terms by 75 per cent. The real value of the pension has increased under this government by around 14 per cent. All of those things will be preserved because under this government all family payments, all social security payments, are indexed to the CPI. So any increase in prices as a result of the tax changes will feed automatically into higher benefits for people and families on low incomes. In all these ways, the least well-off are protected.

Moreover, in the context of the tax cuts, the special $100 tax rebate for low income earners is designed to extend down to people in the under $20,700 category—that benefit of $2 per week is enjoyed by people at the lower end of the tax category. The tax changes are worth $2 a week to people on around $23,000. That is put down into that lower level. It is the case that the bulk of the personal tax cuts are quite deliberately targeted at middle Australia because that is the group in this society that has not benefited as much from tax cuts in the past.

The other dimensions of the budget strategy speak for themselves. If Senator Kernot wants to ask me about petrol later, I will be happy to answer that in more detail. The short point is that there is a very serious health policy objective and environmental objective underlying that as well as the revenue consideration and that is something which is in everyone's interests in this community to achieve. In particular, I would have thought that Senator Kernot's party would be the first to appreciate the significance of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister has done all these marvellous things for low income earners in the period of the Labor government, why is it then that under this Labor government's policies the gap between the rich and the poor in Australia has never been greater? Why should unemployed Australians have to wait one more year for a white paper and for the rest of the world to catch up to provide the government with solutions which it has been unable to find?

—I do not know what the basis is for the assertion about gaps between rich and poor. All I know is that on the basis of the material that I have seen and on the basis of the information in front of me, we have done an enormous amount for lower income people and lower income families. There have been substantial real gains in all the areas that I have mentioned over the whole tenure of this government. So far as job growth is concerned, I can do no more than repeat what I said. Senator Kernot can huff and puff and try to blow the house down but the only way we will get that job growth is by a combination of strategies locking together in the way that I have described, of which this budget is a crucial component.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the recent ASEAN post-ministerial conference held in Singapore in July, which was attended by Senator Evans. I note that the conference covered much ground of direct interest to Australia. Could the Minister inform the Senate of how the outcomes of the meeting will further our international interests and contribute towards our foreign policy objectives as they relate to the region. What are the benefits for Australia in the further development of a sense of regional community in the Asia-Pacific region?

—Contrary to some possible appearances, this is not exactly a question I sought because I thought I might have my hands full on other matters today. Nonetheless, it is a question that I am very happy to answer. I am particularly happy to answer that question because it is the case that Australian foreign policy is on a bit of a roll at the moment, as was demonstrated by the events in Singapore, in particular, a couple of weeks ago. In the nature of things, that condition might not last forever so I am determined to enjoy it. So I am happy to answer the question.

PARA.TAB: It is important to appreciate that there is a rapidly and dramatically growing new sense of regional community—an Asia-Pacific regional community—in which Australia is unequivocally part and perceived of as an active and effective partner which has both a security dimension and an economic dimension. So far as the security dimension is concerned, what was achieved at the Singapore meeting three weeks ago was the agreement to establish a new regional security forum in which not just the existing ASEAN countries and their traditional dialogue partners—Australia, New Zealand, Japan, Korea, Canada and the United States—would participate but, in addition, Russia, China, Vietnam, Laos and Papua New Guinea as well. In other words, all the major security players, in particular Russia and China, have been brought together into a regional forum where serious and systematic discussion will take place of the whole range of politico-security issues with which we are intimately and crucially concerned.

It was further agreed that the kinds of themes that would be addressed by that forum in the future would be weapons non-proliferation, transparency in both armaments and force structure, military policy generally and strategic discussion, and also development of the concept of preventive diplomacy. There was specific consideration also, of course, in Singapore of some regional security subissues like Cambodia—which Senator Hill will be desperately disappointed to have to now acknowledge has been a success—and the situation in Burma, where I am pleased to say there is increasing evidence of pressure being really exerted by the countries that really matter so far as Burma is concerned, namely, its ASEAN neighbours, to produce hopefully a more civilised result there.

On the other side of the equation—the economics of the Asia-Pacific region—again there have been some major achievements. The whole existence of APEC is now regarded as thoroughly consolidated. The leaders meeting, which is being convened at the end of this year by President Clinton, unquestionably will go ahead and inject major new momentum and, as our Prime Minister has said, horsepower into that process.

It has been acknowledged that alternative views of how the region might move itself forward economically—like, for example, the East Asia economic caucus concept—are best regarded as subsets, as components of that larger regional APEC strategy, rather than in any way competitors for it.

The evidence is that in all these ways the members of the region are acting and thinking more alike, identifying common objectives and generally acting and responding to each other in a way that represents a much greater degree of ease and comfort in the relationships between governments and nations around the region than has ever previously been the case. That is exactly the kind of thing that we have been on about in terms of Australian foreign policy and what we have been trying to achieve in our own modest way in the region. The fact that these things are coming together is, I believe, a very significant achievement not only for the region but for Australian foreign policy.

PARA.TAB: I did not get down the details of all the categories that Senator Newman mentioned in her question. I assure her that I will take the question on notice and get back to her with the detail of those examples.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Clearly the Minister for Family Services does not know much about what is happening to Australia's families. It is obvious that she has as much trouble as Martin Ferguson in trying to defend the indefensible.
—Order! Ask the supplementary question.

—When the minister considers the cost to Australia's families as I have described, will she also take into account their extra pharmaceutical costs, the extra cost of having their children's eyes tested and any other matters that she cares to take into account and tell us truthfully how that family will make out as a result of the government's harsh regime that was introduced last night?

—It is quite inappropriate and improper for Senator Newman to suggest that I would find a line or a dishonest answer to her question. I will certainly take account of the points that she made in the first part of her question and in her supplementary question. TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, refers to the action taken by the government on environmental grounds, amongst others, to increase the price of leaded petrol viciously. As the Treasurer said last night, this measure recognises the harmful effects of lead in petrol, particularly on children in Australia. Can the minister kindly inform us whether there is a problem with chemical emissions in South Australia, Tasmania and regional Australia to the extent that that action is warranted? Further, can the minister indicate how many children have blood lead levels above the proposed new health standard in both those states?

—I have been advised by the minister for the environment, Mrs Kelly, that the National Health and Medical Research Council has concluded, on the best available national and international scientific information, that intellectual impairment in children occurs at much lower blood lead levels than previously thought, thus exposing many more children to this risk. The NHMRC has recommended a reduction of the safe levels of lead in blood from 25 micrograms per decilitre to less than 10 micrograms per decilitre. The NHMRC has called for immediate action to reduce exposure to lead, particularly in children aged one to four years. If no action were taken, it has been estimated that the percentage of children up to four years with blood levels in excess of the new goal would be 33 per cent in 1996 and 24 per cent in 1998.

PARA.TAB: About 90 per cent of lead in the air comes from lead in petrol. Australian vehicles are estimated to have the highest per capita level of lead emissions in the world. There is overwhelming evidence amongst OECD nations that decreases in average levels of lead in air are largely attributable to reductions in the use of lead in petrol. Most other OECD countries have introduced a price differential to encourage motorists to switch from leaded to unleaded petrol.

The current phase-out of leaded petrol by the year 2002 is still not quick enough to meet the new NHMRC standards. That is why the government has announced the phasing in of a price differential for leaded and unleaded fuel. I do not have available an answer to Senator Harradine's specific question about numbers of children. However, I will refer it to Mrs Kelly and see whether she has that information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the minister a question to which he has not responded. He talked about the National Health and Medical Research Council report, which is not yet publicly available. He indicated that the minister has advised him that 33 per cent of children may be over that standard. Is the minister aware that a study of 130 children at the Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne has shown that 96 per cent of those children were actually under the proposed very strict new standard? Is this not a revenue collecting decision which will impact on the poorest people, particularly people in his state and in my state? For example, the average age of cars in my state is 11.1 years compared with the national average of 9.8 years.

—I would have thought, Senator Harradine, that the number one issue in this country is the health of our children, not whether a particular state could be affected by particular levels of lead or whether it is a states rights issue. I believe that the government has taken a decision to address the issue of lead in petrol as it affects our children. As far as the differential is concerned, that is not an issue which has motivated the government.

PARA.TAB: Judging by Senator Harradine's long history in this place of expressing his concerns about families and children, I would have thought he would have been the first to support us in protecting the health of children. I will refer to Mrs Kelly the request for the information that I do not have available and will report back later.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask the minister to explain why his government has placed a devastating 50 per cent sales tax hike on the wine industry, one of Australia's most rapidly growing export industries, when that industry needs a buoyant domestic market as a base from which to develop an overseas market?

—It is important to appreciate what we have not done with the wine industry, which is what the wine industry most feared and about which there was most pre-budget speculation, and that is impose a whopping great increase in excise. That did not occur. The truth of the matter is that the impost represented by the increase in the wholesale sales tax will not, in our judgment, make a major dent, in any significant way, in an industry that is booming, that is doing brilliantly well in terms of export markets, and that we fully expect not only to survive but also to flourish locally.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister obviously has not been talking to the wine growers I have spoken to in the last 24 hours. Can the minister reconcile the statement by the Treasurer that the primary objective of the budget is jobs with the fact that the Wine Makers Federation of Australia has halved its expectations of wine exports by the year 2000 by $500 million? How can an industry that has been, according to the chief executive of Orlando Wyndham Wines, Mr Perry Gunner, `chopped off at the knees' employ more people when the government increases the tax on wine by 50 per cent?

—For a start, I do not know what the expectations were that have been diminished in that way. Every projection I have seen about the future of the Australian wine industry demonstrates an exponential growth path into Europe which is fully expected to be sustained, particularly in our own region, as consumer tastes and preferences are dramatically changing and as we expect to get a piece of that action. PARA.TAB: The second point is that the wholesale sales tax increase we are talking about from 20 to 30 per cent is applicable only to domestic wine sales and has nothing to do with exports. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Is the minister aware of criticism by the Tasmanian minister responsible for heritage matters that the Commonwealth government is dragging its feet on providing tax relief for work done on heritage buildings by private owners? When did the government announce its intention to introduce such a scheme? Does the measure announced last night meet that commitment?

—I am aware of those extraordinary remarks by the minister responsible for heritage in Tasmania. I suppose he was trying to divert attention from the gross negligence of the Tasmanian government with regard to heritage matters. Tasmania has more than 1,000 heritage places on the register of the National Estate. It is a state, uniquely, in which heritage is important for tourism and for many other aspects of the Tasmanian economy, yet it has failed to put in place even the most basic safeguards to protect this legacy. It is the only state in Australia without heritage legislation.

PARA.TAB: It attempts to say that the solution to the problem is for us to introduce the tax measures and that we are somehow dragging our feet. This government announced in February that it was going to do this and it has done it in the first budget after the announcement. The tax incentive scheme for heritage conservation works, which was announced last night, cannot redress all the failings of the Tasmanian government. There may be some very important buildings not on the register of the National Estate which would be registered under proper state legislation. Those works will not be eligible for the tax scheme because they are not on the appropriate state or national register.

We cannot make up for the inadequacies of the Tasmanian government, but it is, nevertheless, full implementation of our election commitment, and it will be a very important initiative in a number of ways. Private owners of heritage-listed properties will be able to apply through a competitive selection process for a tax rebate of 20c in the dollar. The scheme will be capped at a revenue cost each year of $2 million, so generating heritage conservation works to the value of $10 million per year.

It is very important from a heritage protection point of view, but it has broader and important ramifications. For a start, to everybody but apparently the Tasmanian government, heritage conservation work is by its nature highly labour intensive. It creates jobs; $10 million worth of work will create more jobs there than any other $10 million in the construction area. Doing it through the tax system in the way we are is a very effective use of the revenue to generate more jobs. It will generate jobs in specialised trades. Equally important is where the jobs will be created. Very many of the eligible heritage buildings which could well be subject to this important scheme—and it is not up to us to choose them because the owners have to apply; we cannot go out and pick the buildings—are in regional areas away from the large metropolitan areas and very many of them are in the regional towns and cities of Tasmania.

In contrast to the dilatory attitude of the Tasmanian government on this and some other heritage matters about which I have been in discussion with them, I am very optimistic that they will keep their promise and move to implement some legislation in this regard. I hope they do. The government has moved to stimulate work in the area of heritage conservation. It is very important for the preservation of our heritage, it is very important to create jobs, it is very important for regional development, and it is a very effective use of the taxpayers' money to achieve a wide range of proper economic, social and cultural objectives. We look forward to the cooperation of all states. As we welcome cooperation from the other five, we look forward to it from the Tasmanian government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for giving me the opportunity to ask a question before making my maiden speech. My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Last night's budget increased the burden of wool tax on growers from 8 1/2 per cent to 12 per cent. Given that only 4 1/2 per cent is needed for debt repayment, can the minister assure the industry that the rest of the tax will be used only for wool promotion and nothing else? If not, why is the government insisting on strangling this industry, which is hurting beyond comprehension?
—Who cares, Cookie, who cares?
—Senator Hill interjects, `Who cares?'. The government does care. You may not care, but we do.

PARA.TAB: The government's position on both wool promotion funding and the wool tax has been known for a considerable time. The wool tax comprises three separate components: first, a tax to help fund the operations of the Wool Realisation Commission, which is responsible for selling the wool stockpile and discharging the wool industry debt; secondly, a wool promotion levy; and, thirdly, a research and development levy. The prescribed levels of each tax component under current legislation are 8 per cent, 3.5 per cent and 0.5 per cent, respectively.

I should also say that in June last year the government reduced the effective level of the wool tax to the debt management component from 8 per cent to 4.5 per cent by declaring a rebate to growers on the basis of stronger than expected performance by the Wool Realisation Commission during the year 1991-92. This gave an overall effective wool tax rate of 8.5 per cent for the 1992-93 year. On 28 April this year the government agreed that there was no capacity to declare the wool realisation rebate for 1993-94 but, in recognition of the current circumstances facing woolgrowers, the return to the 12 per cent prescribed tax rate would be delayed for one year—that is, until July 1994.

I am sure Senator Sandy Macdonald is aware that the level of wool tax allocated to wool promotion is recommended to the government by the annual general meeting of the Australian Wool Corporation and that the annual general meeting recommended a rate of 3.5 per cent for the 1993-94 year, which the government has now accepted. In regard to the suggestion to increase the wool tax for promotion—that runs counter to the government's approach, which aims to reduce rather than increase the burden of wool promotion funding on growers—the government is actively working with the International Wool Secretariat and the International Wool Textile Organisation to develop a broader funding base to reduce the burden on woolgrowers. I might say as well that the Garnaut report contains some recommendations on wool promotion. Of course, the government will consider those recommendations, along with all of the other recommendations of that report, and respond to them appropriately in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Why is the government now aiming to save only $25 million in this financial year and $65 million next year from over-servicing and fraud under Medicare and the PBS when it predicted during the election campaign that some $410 million should be saved? What has changed since the election? Does the minister now rule out the introduction of tough new legislative measures to tackle this problem, as called for the by the Auditor-General and Mr Harvey Bates in his review of Health Insurance Commission procedures? Why is the minister catering to the interests of just a handful of medical practitioners while, at the same time, he is asking Australians to accept the abolition of Medicare benefits for eye tests?

—Upon getting this job, I took it upon myself to have a long look at the question of fraud and over-servicing, the success of the government over the years in attempting to curb it and where we would go with that in the future.
—What about the co-payment? That would have helped a bit.

—Actually, at the time of the co-payment there was no change at all in the usage of Medicare but that is another story. I therefore had a look at what we had been doing over the years. It is certainly true that, while we have had some success, we have not reached the savings targets for some time. So I wanted to make sure that, if I were to have an influence in putting figures into the budget, they would be figures that were attainable, not figures that we would later have to be disappointed about.
—You are blushing for a change.
—No, I am not blushing at all. I am quite relaxed about this question.
—Why don't you just say that it was wrong?

—Let me finish the answer. If Senator Herron takes a deep breath he will get there. I then discussed the problem with the HIC, including Mr Bates. I listened to what the HIC had to say and I listened to the direction in which it wanted to go. In so far as it claimed to have been disadvantaged by inadequate legislation concerning fraud, I agreed with it. I have therefore given an undertaking to introduce some legislation to make prosecutions easier and convictions more attainable. That legislation will be before the parliament later this year; presumably it will not be debated until next year, depending upon the outcome of discussions over the next few hours.

PARA.TAB: That having been done, I got to the question of over-servicing. As well as listening to the HIC, I talked to a lot of people in the medical profession, including—but not only—people from the AMA. Of course, I also got some advice from the department. It seemed to me that there has been over time great resistance from the profession on over servicing and I think that is the main reason why some of the savings targets were not reached. That being the case, I set about looking at a new regime and talked to the AMA, along with the HIC, about genuine peer pressure and review. I thought that if we could go down that route it was worth trying because the solely HIC route which we had pursued in recent years did not seem to be producing all the results that we wanted.

We are now looking at figures that are attainable. I am confident not only that we will attain them but that we will do considerably better. I did not seek to put in optimistic figures; I put in very conservative ones. I was speaking to Brendan Nelson yesterday, and he thinks there will be more savings than those we have put in the budget. It is a conservative figure. All honourable senators will get an opportunity to look at it over the next year. I am sure that those targets will be reached. The legislation for the new regime on over-servicing, of which I have just spoken, will be introduced as soon as possible. I will try to have it in before due dates and have it dealt with during these sittings of parliament.

The last part of Senator Lees's question asked why we were doing these things yet still doing away with optometry. One is looking at an overview, and doing a whole range of things. As far as optometry is concerned, it is not the kind of decision that one would take in good times; it is a hard decision for a hard time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the minister to figures contained in the wool industry table 3.169 of budget paper No. 1. I further refer the minister to the statement on page 4.17 that the wool tax will rise to 12 per cent. The figures stated in the table relate to a wool tax of 8.5 per cent, not 12 per cent. I therefore ask: are the figures in the table wrong, is the statement wrong, or does the Treasurer—Slugger Dawkins—intend to raise the wool tax and further hurt cash strapped woolgrowers?
—Order! You will use senators' and members' proper names.

—Mr President, I do not have the budget papers that have been referred to by page and by item in front of me, so I cannot confirm the accuracy of the quotations that Senator Crane has given me. But, for the sake of this answer, I will accept Senator Crane as an accurate reporter on what is contained in the budget papers and respond accordingly.

PARA.TAB: I think the problem may well be that Senator Crane tends to read opposition press releases about the wool tax more than he familiarises himself with the facts of the wool tax. Thus he, like a lot of other Australians who may innocently take the opposition as being truthful on this matter, has been misled into a misunderstanding of what does apply. It is only with that explanation that one can understand the question Senator Crane has put to me.

The wool tax rate is set by legislation at 12 per cent but, in the 1992-93 year, a rebate was provided which in fact had the impact of reducing the tax to 8.5 per cent. As I explained in the answer to the last question, the government has decided to continue that until 30 June 1994, as I am informed, at which point the tax rate will revert to the 12 per cent legislated rate. The rebate, which reduces the amount provided for, has been provided because of the better than expected performance of the Wool Realisation Commission and because of the concern the government has for woolgrowers. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. To allay the minister's fears that I might be quoting from some press release, I point out that page 4.17 states: `From 1 July 1994 the wool tax is to rise from 8.5 per cent to 12 per cent'. This does not relate to the figures in the outlay. I ask the minister again: which is correct—the 8.5 per cent or the 12 per cent?

—I can repeat the answer. I did not accuse Senator Crane of quoting from a press release. I said that if he is quoting from the budget papers, that is fine, but he may misunderstand the budget papers by relying on the interpretation in the opposition press release. The tax as it stands at the present time, by virtue of the rebate provided, is at 8.5 per cent. That tax is adjusted according to the annual performance of the market, the Wool Realisation Commission and, in the government's view, the needs of wool producers.

PARA.TAB: The underlying rate is 12 per cent; we make an assessment each year. As the government has said, it will continue the last assessment to keep it at 8.5 per cent through to 30 June 1994. At that time it will return to the prescribed rate of 12 per cent. I would have thought that was a fairly clear explanation but, if it is not, I can put it in writing for Senator Crane.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to recent comments from the business community that, despite major restructuring in the waterfront industry, the performance of Australian ports still needs to be improved. What evidence is there that the government's reforms are taking effect and that waterfront charges paid by users are reducing?
—Mr President—
—Don't look in the mirror.
—I am cut to the quick by those comments about my tie.
—There is so much of it.
—It takes a while to get to my quick, too. This is the Sydney Olympic bid tie, Senator Hill.
—It will frighten them away.
—I would take him to task if I were you, Senator Baume.
—It will stand out in the crowd.

—I must admit that it would look a lot better on Carl Lewis than on me; I concede that. In the past week, three major studies were released, clearly demonstrating the substantial efficiency gains made in the maritime industry under the government's micro-economic reform agenda. However, the government fully recognises that reform is a dynamic process and the government is committed to achieving a great deal more.

PARA.TAB: The PSA's second monitoring report on stevedoring confirms the earlier trend of significant and sustained reductions in stevedoring costs flowing from waterfront reform. Furthermore, it finds that these productivity gains have been substantially passed on in terms of lower prices to shipping lines. From 1990 to the end of 1992, the PSA estimates that average container terminal charges declined by 25 per cent. Over the past seven years, to the end of 1992, the real price of container terminal stevedoring charges has fallen by 67 per cent.
This report provides valuable data for shippers to continue exerting commercial pressures in their negotiation of freight rates with shipping companies to maximise the flow-on of reforms.
The PSA's towage report is the first report in the monitoring of tug charges in major ports affected by towage reforms pursued under the government's shipping reform program.

The Prices Surveillance Authority has found that tug crewing costs—the major focus of reform and the major cost component of towage—have fallen by 9 per cent in the two years to the end of 1992. The PSA concludes that this was instrumental in restraining towage charges generally around Australia. However, price increases occurring in some ports reflected the offset of these cost cuts by increases in other operating charges, particularly administrative costs. The government is going to have a look at that.

Towage operators recently foreshadowed their support for further industry reforms and the PSA report suggests some specific areas for review. I am encouraging the industry to continue developing new reform strategies.

The third report highlights the overall performance improvement in the port sector from micro-economic reform. The first report on government trading enterprises performance indicators has found that port authority labour productivity increased by 88 per cent in the five years to June 1992—the highest overall improvement among all government trading enterprises. This reflected a 40 per cent decline in the port work force around Australia.

However, the report notes that performance gains are uneven and the Bureau of Industry Economics report on waterfront performance shows that port charges are still high by world standards, highlighting the need for further reform.
