TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Lees this day, relating to Medicare.

SPEECH.PARA: In an answer to a question by Senator Lees about savings from clamping down on fraud in Medicare, Senator Richardson claimed that, if he were to be involved in putting some figures in the budget, he would make sure that those figures were attainable. He stood here and said that he would make sure that those figures were attainable. How can we believe Senator Richardson? When he was Minister for Social Security, he introduced the data matching legislation, which we in this chamber were very concerned about, and estimated savings of $300 million a year. That is what Senator Richardson said we would get. He stood there and promised us that we would get $300 million a year.

PARA.TAB: The coalition and the Australian Democrats sent it off to a Senate inquiry because we were very concerned about it. I think Senator Spindler was at that inquiry. He will remember that Senator Richardson said, `Yes, we'll guarantee $300 million'. So Australians gave up some more of their privacy for that very reason, and we will see Australians giving up more of their privacy with his attempt to correct Medicare fraud. I am not objecting to that; I am objecting to the fact that Senator Richardson makes promises he cannot keep. He did so during the election campaign and he is doing so again at this stage.

The data matching never reached anywhere near those savings. In fact, the annual savings from data matching are now believed to have peaked at about $70 million a year. We were going to get $300 million a year. It peaked at $70 million a year, which is less than a quarter of the estimate made by Minister Richardson. So we will all be watching very carefully to see what he will achieve with Medicare since he was not able to achieve his promises in social security.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), I believe it is quite clear that he has not got the faintest idea how much is going to be recovered from fraud and that he mixes up fraud with overservicing. In relation to fraud, over four years the government has managed to get back only about $250,000. Lord knows what amount of money was spent on prosecution—
—But then Keating caved in on the co-payment to get a vote.

—That is right, and now he is plucking out a figure of $25 million. Yet in May this year I asked a question in this chamber as to where the figure was coming from for $410 million at that stage—it has gone from $410 million to $25 million now in the budget last night. The minister still has not got the faintest idea, as he said in response to the very good question from Senator Lees, even where that figure is coming from. It is still winging around the edges there. He is going to pluck it out of the air somewhere along the line when somebody comes up with something.
—With the feathers.

—That is right, and so it goes on. He really has not got a concept of what is going on. He comes up with these figures that he is plucking out of the air. I suspect that that is also reflected in the rest of the budget that was handed down last night. I will look with interest as to where that is coming from.

PARA.TAB: I can tell the Senate where the figure of $310 million came from. It came from the Harvey Bates report that was tabled here which stated that in the United States 10 per cent of the total health care budget went on fraud and overservicing. The total health bill in this country is $30 billion and 10 per cent of that is $300 million. That is where the figure came from. The government has transposed the figures from the American health care system, which is totally different from our own. It has taken 10 per cent of the Australian costs of health care and said there is $300 million in fraud and overservicing.

The minister has acknowledged today that he has spent a bit of time talking to people in his portfolio and he has got it down to $25 million. He says it will be $69 million the year after and so it goes into never-never land somewhere along the trail. We will keep him to account on that. After getting back about $250,000 over four years from fraud, it will be very interesting to see how the minister will get that figure to $25 million in the next year. I look forward to seeing where that is going. The minister has the total cooperation of the medical profession of Australia in dealing with fraud. Fraud is unacceptable to any of us.

In relation to overservicing, it will be interesting to see how the minister goes there. Who defines what overservicing is? What is his definition of overservicing? If people want a health check-up before going overseas and a blood test, is it regarded as overservicing because they want a check before they go away? Nobody knows the answer to that problem of definition.

Senator Richardson has the gall to come in and give the other part of the answer to the question in relation to optometry services. The government has selectively knocked off Medicare rebates for people who go to optometrists for eye tests. At least the minister had the ability to blush today in trying to respond to that matter, even though he gave no response to this part of the question. He has selectively attacked the optometrists. Because there are not a large number of optometrists in Australia—fewer than 3,000 overall—the government is able to get away with it. I put the minister on notice now that he must put this through by regulation and not just in a budget paper that goes through. But I suspect that is how he will do it so that it will become an issue for a short period of time.

I know that the optometrists are up in arms throughout this country, even though they are widely dispersed. Speaking for my own state of Queensland, I am aware that in many small towns the optometrist is the only person who is able to provide eye testing services. The families in country towns will be the people particularly affected when they have eye problems that can be serviced only by an optometrist. People with eye problems will have to travel long distances to go to ophthalmologists.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), in response to questions without notice asked by Senator Hill and Senator Short this day, relating to taxation measures in the 1993-94 budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Contrary to the impression that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) attempted to convey today, this is a government and a budget of deceit, of betrayal, of broken promises, of lies and of shattered credibility. This is a budget that savagely increases a wide range of indirect taxes and charges, that produces a tax hike over the next four years alone of an additional $32.2 billion, and it is a budget that leaves every low income family and practically every middle income family worse off, after Labor governments have mercilessly reduced their living standards throughout the past decade.

PARA.TAB: It is a budget that offers no hope to the one million unemployed, and particularly the 400,000 long-term unemployed Australians, of finding a job. It is a budget that viciously further hits Australian families who, on top of the increases in their living costs through the increased sales and excise taxes and the other charge increases, will find that even when they are eligible—there will be only a small proportion who are—to receive the measly reduction in personal income tax, those reductions will not even meet the increase in tax that they will pay from the bracket creep through the tax brackets that the government's increased taxes and charges will produce.

This budget produces a bigger tax take—an additional $32 billion over the next four years—it produces more government spending; and it produces a bigger budget deficit. Senator Evans had the gall to try to tell us today that this budget was on target to lead to a budget deficit reduction of some $10 billion by 1996-97. Indeed, this budget deficit is $16 billion compared with the outcome last year of $14.5 billion. It means that in the past three years, including 1993-94, this government will have drawn on the nation's savings to finance its profligate spending and other policies to the tune of no less than $40 billion.

This budget and the associated government policies will produce a bigger balance of payments deficit. The budget papers forecast the balance of payments deficit blowing out to $18 billion this year compared with $15.5 billion last year and $12 billion or thereabouts the year before. In other words, there will be a 50 per cent further increase in our balance of payments deficit over the past two years alone. Coupled with the 4 per cent plus devaluation in the Australian dollar that is forecast in the budget papers, it will lead to a further huge increase in our debt to foreigners, our debt to the rest of the world and through that, very importantly, there will be a very significant reduction in our sovereignty.

It is incredible that at a time when the government is talking about the problems that Australia has in terms of a lack of independence around the world—which is absolute nonsense anyway—it takes policy measures which, more than anything else, damage and reduce our independence and our sovereignty. This budget produces a threefold increase in inflation; it produces a further very significant fall in our national savings; it leads to no increase in investment; and it leads to an inevitable rise in interest rates. This is a budget, as is the government that produced it, that is full of deceit, betrayal and lack of vision. It is a directionless budget of lost opportunity. As Alan Ramsey said today in the Sydney Morning Herald:
It's a wonder Paul Keating and John Dawkins can look themselves in the mirror this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak to Senator Short's motion and refer to the answer given by Senator Gareth Evans—in particular, his comment that the government is virtually powerless to do anything about increasing jobs for people who are now on the scrap heap. Among other things, he said that the government is doing all it can to increase our export capacity—a topic that was addressed in more detail later on by Senator Cook. But both of those Ministers seemed to be waxing lyrical about the export enhancement measures that are in this budget—$94 million worth. Leaving aside whether $94 million worth of export enhancement measures is sufficient and whether they will be properly applied and directed, it is very clear that this is only one side of the trade equation.

PARA.TAB: In the last 12 months, we had merchandise export increases of nine per cent—a creditable figure. However, when we look at imports of merchandise, we find that the figure is 17 per cent—almost double. I would have thought that commonsense demands that when one wants to take action, one takes specific action in the area that lends itself to a particularly broad target. Yet the budget is devoid of any measures that give succour to our industries and enable them to meet, with import replacement strategies, the rising tide of cheap imports.

There is absolutely nothing in this budget. Australian industries have been forgotten in this budget; so too have the workers who either now do not have a job or soon will not have a job because the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) do not see that they have a responsibility to do something about protecting our industries. Yet, when we look at other countries—the United States, Korea, Taiwan and European Community nations—we find that at very short notice, whenever it is necessary, they do protect their industries and their workers. They are not worried about the theoretical provisions of GATT; they find a way around them. They use article 12 and article 19—two articles that our government has not been prepared to use in support of our industries and our workers.

I refer the minister to the article, published in the Bulletin today, by Trevor Sykes who goes in some detail into the evidence that I have provided to the inquiry into tariffs and industry development. The record is on the table: other nations are protecting their industries; we are prepared to deliver our industries to the slaughter house; and we are prepared to deliver our workers to the scrap heap.

I believe that this budget is an impotent budget in this respect. I repeat: it purports to deal with trade. All it does is deal with exports; it neglects the other side of the equation, imports, which will cost us hundreds of thousands of dollars in the next few years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up the government's responses to two questions, and that is why I am supporting Senator Short's motion. The Commonwealth Employment (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1992 passed last year in the Senate contained four government amendments. That is one of the reasons it is vital to give the Senate enough time to deal with these things properly. That was just as well because if those government amendments had not taken place, presumably we would have had another bit of correcting legislation. Better legislation is what we are here for; we are a house of review. TALK.START.PARA: —In the late 1980s Senate motions setting deadlines for the consideration of legislation came into vogue and have colloquially been called the Macklin amendment. In the past, the cut-off point has usually been late November or late May. The government was not ecstatic at the time these particular reforms were introduced in the Senate but, nevertheless, I think we learnt to live with the deadlines. It meant inevitable changes in the procedures in the House of Representatives and far more rigorous use of the guillotine to meet the Macklin deadline. Because there was more limited debate in the House of Representatives, it probably required more extensive debate to occur in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Of course the Chamarette motion, as it will be known if it is passed, is radically different. It requires legislation to be introduced in the House of Representatives by 1 October—that is, three and a half sitting weeks after the commencement of the sitting period. Some legislation can be introduced into the Senate up until 29 October. Of course the real key to this is that money bills cannot be introduced in the Senate; they must originate in the House of Representatives. If a money bill is not ready by 1 October, it cannot meet one of the loopholes to come through the Senate first between 1 October and 29 October. I think that will present some substantial difficulties in the future.

Whether intended or unintended, a consequence is that bills will not come into this chamber through the originating minister between 1 October and 29 October. Traditionally, the way the two houses of parliament operate for the most part is that the minister responsible for the bill introduces it into the chamber in which he or she resides. It then proceeds to the other chamber. Now we will have a less than adequate process where bills that are not drafted by 1 October will be introduced here by ministers who represent ministers in the House of Representatives and thus have less knowledge of the bills and are not making the first definitive statement on it. I do not believe that will be a constructive development in terms of the way the houses of parliament operate.

The records show—as do the figures that Senator Chamarette tabled today—that normally only 15 per cent of legislation reaches the houses of parliament by 1 October. Those senators, such as the Greens, who have had absolutely no experience of executive government, grossly underestimate the work that is required to draft bills and to bring them to finality before they are presented to parliament. This is exacerbated in the case of budget bills. We introduced the budget on 17 August. Under this motion, we would be required to have the drafting instructions of all budget bills not only issued but brought to fruition by 1 October.

In many ways, what Senator Baume said here today can be reversed: if you put undue and enormous pressure on the parliamentary draftsmen, there will be far more errors in this legislation by inadvertence than otherwise. I accept his argument on this issue, but he also has to accept mine. If we put enormous pressure on the Office of Parliamentary Counsel to rush the bills, there will be many mistakes. With all the ability in the world, this Senate does not always pick them up. No matter how much time we devote to legislation, we are not necessarily capable of picking up every minor drafting error or unintended consequence.

It should be further stated that if as a result of the Chamarette motion we are placed under the pressure of having to get done first all the budget bills—those with a money element that come out of the House of Representatives—the drafting of other bills inevitably will have to wait to be introduced into this chamber, irrespective of the originating minister.

It is proper to reflect that there has been a change in the approach of this Senate in terms of the time it devotes to its business generally. I believe that we are now sitting many more days than we have in the past and for much longer hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we are dealing with a lot more bills.

—We are dealing with a lot more bills. It might be asserted by Senator Baume or others that this is legislation gone mad or that it is an ideological predilection of this government to have so many bills. But it is also a reflection of an increasingly complex world in which litigation is far more likely and issues concerning federal government are far more complex than they have been in the past.

PARA.TAB: Remember all the primary industry bills we bring into this place. Perhaps some thought should be given to the reason we do this year by year. Why can we not make them three- or four-year bills? We probably deal with 30 or 40 primary industry bills over a calendar year. That again puts enormous pressure on available time, especially because members of the National Party, as a matter of electoral necessity, have to speak on every one. Once one speaks from one state, all the rest from the other states have to speak lest their preselection be in some way questioned for lack of application.

TALK.START.PARA: —We speak on agricultural bills, too.

—Certainly the rump of the Western Australian Liberal Party has been most active on these particular matters. But Senator Panizza is really a National Party member in disguise. We know that he has a secret National Party ticket hidden in his back pocket somewhere—ticket No. 14362. Senator Panizza can try to deny it.
—It expired in 1985.

—I see. It is amazing how when you throw a spear you get a result. I have to assert that the Senate does not exist simply to consider legislation, although that remains its most crucial role. What is embodied in the Greens motion is changing, to some extent, the ratio between the time this chamber spends on legislation and the time it spends on articulating the concerns of its constituents or, indeed, checking the accountability of executive government.

PARA.TAB: I wonder what mandate the Greens have to introduce this motion. We can probably dismiss as too base the motive that it was merely a squeeze play to get extra staff. While I have not made a totally exhaustive search, I have yet to find anything on the public record to show where they have been public on this issue prior to Senator Chamarette moving her motion. I wonder whether the 75,440 Western Australian electors had this motion on their mind when they voted for Senator Valentine in 1990. Certainly when she asked for our preferences she did not raise this as an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't have petrol taxes in mind when they voted for you.

—Probably because they did not raise this as an issue. I wonder what the 53,211 electors had on their mind when they voted for Senator Margetts. Was it bringing in a cut-off motion in the Senate? Was that ever mentioned in the campaign? Was it ever raised once as an issue? Mandates are very flexible things, so I will not make too big a point of it. But the fact is that the subject of this motion has never been taken to the public as an issue. What we are seeing is the classic case of proportional representation being a marvellous way of distributing representation and an appalling way of distributing power.

PARA.TAB: This motion would have no viability whatsoever but for the support of opposition senators. Here they are—embittered by defeat, frustrated by thwarted ambition and debilitated by intellectual torpor. They have finally adopted the total opposition mentality and proved once again that they are not fit to govern. Their embattled leader, Dr Hewson, has hinted at blocking supply at the very same time as they are trying to resurrect Malcolm Fraser into the federal presidency of the Liberal Party.

Is it not interesting that the Liberal Party is in power in Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania? Have those state governments voluntarily introduced a cut-off motion themselves, if this is such a marvellous principle as espoused by the opposition? None of them has touched it or gone near it, yet they have the same legislative difficulties we have with legislation coming in late in the sittings. This is an example of the opposition's ideological acolytes in the states ignoring their principles as espoused in the Senate. We are seeing a cynical opportunistic move by the opposition. Why do not Mr Kennett, Mr Groom and Mr Fahey adopt this policy?

I am someone with a reasonable memory. I can remember in 1989 former senator Chaney, the then leader of the Liberal Party in this chamber, explaining to me in the corridor after one of our procedural meetings that these cut-off motions were a waste of time and that he did not agree with them in principle. I said, `Could this road to Damascus conversion be that there is a federal election coming up next year and that, having stuck it up us for years, you do not want this as a precedent applying to you?'. That was a very cynical view of mine. I am sure that it was a principled position by former senator Fred Chaney!

Hark back to the spring session of last year—1992. The Australian Democrats moved their cut-off motion. Did the opposition support them? No, it did not. Did it indicate to them that it would not support them? Yes, it did. Why? What is the coincidence? There was another change of policy in 1992. Because there was a federal election coming up in 1993 and opposition senators did not want any of these provisions applying to them, they thought that if they kicked it out the back door in November-December 1992 they would not have to worry about it in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since we are being so frank, why didn't you tell the electorate about increasing petrol taxes?

—We are concentrating on the hypocritical approach that the opposition is showing. Honourable senators did not support a cut-off motion last year because they did not want it applying to them. That is typical opposition mentality.

PARA.TAB: It is no coincidence that in late 1989 and in 1992, just before federal elections, cut-off motions were not considered to be a good idea. But let us put the acid test on the opposition right now. Presumably Senator Alston will be the next speaker. When he rises, I want him to give us a cast-iron guarantee that, if the opposition ever wins government, he personally will move this sort of cut-off motion. I want him to put it in writing. We will not see it.

The opposition has no intention of supporting this motion in terms of principle. It is part of that mentality that Mr Fischer expressed the other day when he said, `What we will have in the Senate is trench warfare'. The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, the General Haig of the First World War, Senator Hill, is absolutely perfect at this sort of trench warfare. Not only will he kill thousands of others; he will end up shooting himself in the foot.

I have some sympathy with the proposals put forward by the Australian Democrats because I believe that they are far more reasonable and effective than those put forward by the Greens here today. In summary, I do not think this motion will either support or encourage the democratic process or be in the interests of the Australian electorate as a whole. It is now espoused by two representatives who have been, I think, badly used by the opposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —Elected on your preferences!

—They were elected with 0.63 per cent of the total vote cast formally around Australia in the last two Senate elections. They are using the opposition mentality and building on it to put this motion through while representing 0.63 per cent of the Australian Senate electorate.

PARA.TAB: There are a couple of other corollaries of this proposal, but I will firstly turn to the points made by Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine implied here today that the government was using a sleight of hand when proposing that, in terms of Senator Chamarette's motion, we use the term `urgent bills' as though in some way, under the counter, we are trying to use that provision in the standing orders to then make those bills guillotinable. That has never occurred to us and it was never our intention.

We have used the term `urgent bills' outside this chamber in the sense that they are urgent to get through. We would be quite happy in future to change that terminology to `crucial bills', because there was no intention on the part of the government to invoke the section of the standing orders that allows these bills to be declared urgent. I give the assurance to the Senate that that was never part of our agenda and it never occurred to us. That comes from someone who declared 62 bills urgent three years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you do it then?

—I did it on the precedent of Senator Withers in 1977. I point out, whilst this does not apply to Senator Alston, that 11 of his colleagues who were then in parliament voted not only for the guillotine but also to gag the debate on the guillotine.

PARA.TAB: The second point that Senator Harradine has been making strongly in this chamber is whether the drafting instructions should be released. The government resisted that. It gave it consideration, but totally resisted it. In many cases drafting instructions are under way before the policy decision is made, in anticipation of the policy decision. On occasions there is a different policy decision and new drafting instructions are issued. No rational government, be it Labor, Liberal or anything else, would want to put itself in that political position. What has to happen is that policies are determined, drafting instructions are done and then legislation is released. There is absolutely no way the government would support that proposal.

Another point should be made. If indeed this motion to put in cut off dates of 1 October and 29 October is carried, I believe there is an absolute obligation on the Senate to see through that program to the end of its deliberation, and that it must facilitate the fact that these bills should be discussed. No-one can presume that they have to be passed; that is a matter for the numbers in this chamber. If those opposite put this sort of cut off date in, never again would the government expect anybody to come whingeing to us saying that they have not done the Christmas shopping yet and they want to go home without completing the legislative program.

That is a natural corollary of this motion and it really should get a pledge from this chamber that those opposite would meet this particular requirement. If we do not, we know that this is just a cynical move. The sorts of offers that have been made to table the full list of bills by 30 August are a major advance on what has ever occurred in this chamber.

I believe this motion is unworkable. I believe it is not in the interests of the country. It will put enormous pressures, not only in this sitting but also right through the Christmas holidays, on the staff in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, because that is when they will have to work to meet the autumn deadline. There will be no Christmas holidays for them. It will result in far more mistakes.

I do not put on the record a challenge that this was motivated by Senator Chamarette and her colleague through the worst of motives; I put no such thing on the record. But let me assure the two Greens sitting here today that the support for their motion by senators on the other side of the chamber is the most cynically based possible. They did not support such motions at the leadership level in 1989 or in totality in 1992. They do not believe in it for the future.

None of their state colleagues—their friends on occasions—will do this because they are not forced to do so. So it is not a matter of principle over there; it is a matter of trench warfare, expediency and the worst kind of cynicism that one can see in politics. In effect the Greens are setting themselves up to be exploited by those opposite and all they stand for. That leaves the Greens in a very pathetic position. The government persists in its opposition to this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the main problem that we have on our side of the chamber is that from time to time we think that members of the government will actually be persuaded by logic and that they will actually understand what principles are all about. But Senator Ray, unfortunately, has been living proof today of the fact that Labor senators are motivated entirely by cynicism; that what other people might regard as issues of principle, they regard as issues of numbers.

PARA.TAB: I think that Senator Ray on a number of occasions in the past, and certainly in my time in the Senate, has come into this chamber and put propositions which have made good sense and have not always been apparently motivated by party self-interest. But today for him to stand up and say that he was one who was personally responsible for declaring 62 bills urgent, when he was clearly saying in the same breath that he knew darn well they were not, is just an extraordinary example of how Labor does not accept anyone else's bona fides.

If he were objective about this, I think his starting point would be to look at how the business of the parliament has been conducted and precisely what it is that he is trying to achieve. He should do it without impugning people's integrity and without doing this extraordinary gymnastic performance, which I think is impossible, in which he said that he could have people agreeing to support a motion some of whom are `cynical, sleazy, opportunistic and unprincipled' and then find that they are taking the same approach to an issue as others who are merely `misguided, extraordinarily naive and do not understand the ramifications'. One cannot have it both ways.

I would have thought that a much fairer approach would be to say, `What is it that we have been doing in this place in recent times? How have we been handling the business of parliament, and can we do it any better?' The bottom line is to say that it is unworkable, cannot happen, the place comes to a stop and therefore we should not, in any way, contemplate interfering with the way the government wants to do business. In fact implicit in all that is that no-one for a moment questioned the first cut off which has been in place since 1986 and which was proposed by Senator Macklin. In other words, the government has accepted that in all that it has said today and simply went on to say that a double cut off date would be totally unworkable because that is dictating to the House of Representatives. How outrageous!

We had Senator Faulkner saying that this was a constitutional affront. I think he said it was constitutional impertinence to dictate to the House of Representatives and no government can accept that. It is interesting to go back and see what was said in 1986 when Senator Macklin put these proposals forward on the first occasion. Then we had Senator Grimes, who was Manager of Government Business, saying in respect of one cut off proposal only:

SPEECH.PARA: This motion dictates to the other chamber the procedures it should follow in debating the legislation before it.

In other words, seven years ago the government regarded even the first cut off as dictation and blackmail and whatever other pejorative terms one likes to use. But now seven years on it is quite convenient not to trot that out and not to even criticise the first cut off but simply to use the argument in respect of the second cut off.

PARA.TAB: If ever anyone had foresight, it has to have been Senator Grimes. I do not know why he got out of this place, but perhaps he had had enough of the sort of intellectual double dealing that goes on on the other side of the chamber. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think a possible outcome of the motion that Senator Macklin has put is that, as a result of the deadline that this motion may put on the other chamber, it may be the case that if an unscrupulous government were in power—I am not suggesting for one minute that this Government would do it—there would be an increased use of the gag or guillotine in the House of Representatives, therefore stifling the rights of members of that chamber.

If ever there was an eerie forecast about what would happen, it is that. Senator Sherry's former Tasmania colleague was absolutely right and damningly accurate in his judgment of the unscrupulous nature and behaviour of colleagues, many of whom were there at the time and are still here now. Senator Grimes was simply anticipating the way in which this government would get around it: the way it would flaunt and flout the very spirit of a proposal designed to expedite the processes of government.

PARA.TAB: What we have had in recent times in the House of Representatives is a whole swag of legislation dished up or held back until the last moment. People are then expected to make a contribution in 15 minutes or less and they cannot even speak to an amendment. The amendments are just referred to at the end of the debate.

We in this chamber cannot even contemplate the way in which the guillotine and gag motions have been used in the other chamber. So it is absolute hypocrisy to now turn around and pretend that somehow this is dictating to the House of Representatives. As Senator Chamarette has quite rightly said—and after all they proposed this motion and there is no suggestion that somehow we put them up to it or that we are simply the ones—

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't suggest that.

—Even if those opposite did, they would be wrong. The Greens have come to this objectively, of their own accord, as any dispassionate observer would. They look at the way the place runs and they ask, `Is this true?'. My family now accepts that I work up here for a living, particularly when I tell them that we sit through the night; I think we did that on nine occasions in the last session. To find that 92 bills were passed in the last third of the last year's budget sittings gives some idea of the way in which this Senate chamber has operated, the way in which the government has shown absolutely no interest in organising the procedures of the place.

PARA.TAB: I thought that perhaps one of the most breathtaking double standards came from Senator Gareth Evans. He was at pains to contain himself today; it was quite unusual. He was almost the essence of reasonableness. He certainly was not that foul-mouthed individual who blasphemed when he was asked to stop dictating during the proceedings of this chamber yesterday. He certainly was not the bullyboy we often see when he is not getting his own way. There he was, somehow giving the impression that this was all sweetness and light, that the government had come forward with a whole series of compromise proposals which would more than meet any concerns that people might have. To the extent that we still needed to go a bit further, it was a case of `Trust me; we will use our best endeavours; we will get it right'. There is absolutely no reason why anyone should accept any of that.

More importantly, there is no reason why we should not accept the workability of Senator Chamarette's proposal. After all, if the bottom line is simply that there is not enough time to get the drafting right, as Senator Cooney would know, there is any number of underemployed lawyers these days who would be prepared to take on a contract at very short notice. They would probably get paid more than the dock briefs that are accepted on Senator Cooney's side to get up and defend the indefensible on a regular basis. Nonetheless, there would be plenty of people to whom this work could be contracted out. A lot of them would be experts who have actually done drafting work in the past, who have worked in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, and who have all the requisite skills. Whatever one might end up paying them, one would save more from the shortened sitting times.

It is again demonstrably untrue to suggest that the timetable cannot be met. Senator Ray upped the rhetoric a bit by saying it was unworkable. It is all nonsense. There is no reason at all to presume that a timetable which has been checked with all the appropriate authorities—none of whom have cast doubts on its workability—is somehow going to bring the place to a stop.

I will give an example of the sort of casuistry that is employed in this process. After the government had been dragged screaming and yelling into the compromise business, we had a statement recently that its latest proposals had been scrutinised by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel and it had been assured that that office could meet the government's timetable. But the government very carefully did not say whether the office could meet Senator Chamarette's timetable, and I have no doubt at all that it could do just that. But, of course, it was not asked; and, if it was, it was told to shut up if it gave the wrong answer. So, quite clearly the government lacks bona fides on that basis.

If we want to know what this is really all about, we have only to look at the vicious verbal thuggery that was employed by Mr Beazley when these proposals were first put forward and Senator Chamarette actually had the temerity to stand her ground. Mr Beazley accused both the Greens and the opposition of attempting to usurp the role of the lower house. After the government tried to batter them into submission and did not succeed, Mr Beazley said that the Green senators could leave the government budget legislation just rotting around. I do not have any doubt at all that that is the last thing on Senator Chamarette's mind or, indeed, Senator Margett's mind. They are interested in speeding up the process of government. For the minister to behave in that bullyboy fashion shows the true colour of the government's money.

Mr Beazley went on to say that we were both supporting moves which would undermine the authority of the House of Representatives, wreck the Government's budget program, and threaten the constitutional relationship. Finally, he said that the community should not have to stand still for a bunch of bitter opportunists perverting the outcome of the last general election. If ever anyone went over the top it has to have been Mr Beazley whom one would have thought is not the biggest thug in the cabinet; I am sure there are much bigger and more effective thugs around the place than him. If that is the line that he runs, we can imagine what those who are minding him were urging him to say and do. The government's conversion to the cause of reasonableness in terms of process is very belated and I would have thought it is totally lacking in any evidence to support its bona fides. Therefore, why should we not accept the bona fides of Senator Chamarette?

Senator Ray spent most of his time basically trying to attack the integrity of honourable senators on this side of the chamber by suggesting that our motives were entirely impure, that it was simply because we happened to be in opposition at the time. There is no reason to think in the foreseeable future that the numbers in this chamber will change so dramatically that either of the major parties or groupings could expect to dictate the way in which this place operates. I would have thought most objective commentators would say that that was a fairly healthy development. I am sure it outrages and enrages the likes of Senator Richardson; nonetheless, the trouble with democracy is that you actually have to work with people who do not always agree with your propositions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think it makes you too happy either.

—It does not make us happy to be where we are now—I will give the honourable senator that. In the very foreseeable future we would anticipate being where Senator Sherry is now and we will then, I imagine, be stuck with something along these lines. So it is not a matter of somehow, in two or three years time, our coming along and ripping up the rule book and saying, `Righto, from now on we will put in legislation when we feel like it; we will have gags and guillotines till the cows come home—
—You'll change the rules if you ever get the numbers.

—Senator Sherry should not take so cynical an approach. I am very disappointed; Senator Sherry is driven by the numerical imperative as well. I thought that, as a man of principle when it came to superannuation, he might have extended those principles to this debate. But unfortunately, no doubt, he is tainted by his colleagues who have a much tougher view of these matters.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the charts and the details of legislation that has been dealt with in this chamber towards the end of each session, it is abundantly clear that this place has not been working. That is why I was almost on the verge of amusement when Senator Evans—that quiet, mild mannered chap—told us that he had been fuming quietly on the sidelines for many years about the way in which these procedures were not working. He said he was quite unhappy; I think he was almost disconsolate—I do not know whether he was depressed about it. He certainly managed to hold his tongue; he did not come forward with any of those compromise proposals or enlightened suggestions about how we might speed up the business of the chamber. One would have to say that the reality is that Senator Gareth Evans and the rest of those on his side of the chamber were dragged into the position they are in now by the fact that they are not able to get their way in any other manner.

Therefore, I would hope that Senator Richardson, being capable of reasoned debate, will analyse these proposals—not simply from the point of view of attacking others' integrity and suggesting that we are sleazes but the others are merely naive—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Senator Alston, this has been a pretty free-ranging debate but the description of people as `sleazes' and `thugs' is just a little bit beyond parliamentary language. Would you like to withdraw that?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to hear you say that. I trust, therefore, that you will bring Senator Faulkner's attention to that matter because it was a term of endearment that he applied to those on this side of the chamber.
—Senator Alston, I was not in the chair at the time it was used. I am in the chair now and I would respectfully request you to unconditionally withdraw those words.
—If you are asking me to unconditionally withdraw Senator Faulkner's statement that we are sleazy, opportunistic and unprincipled—
—I am asking you to withdraw your statement, Senator Alston. You do not have to compound the sin.

—I just want to be clear, Madam Acting Deputy President, because I have not at any stage suggested that anyone is sleazy. I am simply saying that Senator Faulkner has accused us of that. That might be a widely held view on one side of the chamber but I am not returning the compliment. I am simply—
—Thank you. Would you also like to withdraw your previous use of the word `thug' or `thugs'.
—I think I referred to vicious verbal thuggery. I do not think that was directed to any named individual at the time.
—You said there were better thugs in the cabinet than Mr Beazley.
—Does Senator Richardson regard that as offensive? I thought he would be quite pleased with that. When someone cannot keep a straight face, I find it hard—
—Senator Alston, would you please withdraw that phrase?
—If it offends you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I will withdraw it.
—Thank you.

—I do not have much more to say on this matter simply because I think the facts speak for themselves. There is a better way of doing business. We ought to be concerned about ensuring that the processes work properly and that we do not have the sorts of fiascos that we had with the superannuation guarantee charge legislation being held up for some months because we had been sitting all night and somehow someone managed to overlook one of any number of amendments. If the government is interested in doing things properly, I would have thought it would be prepared to give Senator Chamarette's motion a fair go. Senator Hill has made it very clear that we are not here to adopt any bloody-minded approach. I trust you will not ask me to withdraw that, Madam Acting Deputy President—
—No, Senator.

—We are here to try to improve the processes. If it is demonstrated to us that the government cannot physically work on that timetable, clearly we would have another look at it. If there is genuinely urgent legislation—not 62 Bills in one hit—if there are genuinely unforeseen pieces of legislation that need to be introduced, of course they could always be introduced by a suspension of standing orders or in any other way.

PARA.TAB: We would not stand in the way of any reasonable proposition. That is why we are certainly associating ourselves today with a motion which I believe the Senate will adopt. I hope that the government will then act in a spirit of goodwill and do its very best to facilitate the working of the motion and to give effect to the wishes of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly will not use some of the unparliamentary language that Senator Alston used. I thought that his description of the opposition as opportunistic and unprincipled was good enough; I would not have taken it any further. I have been here only 10 years. There are some who have been here longer.
—Too long, Richo.

—Thanks very much, Senator. I would have to say that it is at moments like this, when one has to enter a debate such as this, that it does feel like it has been too long. In that 10 years the procedures of the place have changed pretty dramatically. If one goes back and looks at how long it took to put things through, particularly with the committee systems, one will see that there have been dramatic changes in the Senate in the last 10 years, all of which have been designed to give all senators a greater opportunity to understand and examine legislation, to probe, push and seek amendment where necessary.

PARA.TAB: The government has assisted that process. It has gone along with that process and, at times, it has encouraged that process, as well we should. But when we get to the point where attempts to push that process any further start to impair the capacity to govern, then we have to draw the line. There are some specifics in this motion with which I disagree. I do not dispute the motives; I just dispute the result. The government wants to improve the place, just as Senator Chamarette does.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I think we have demonstrated that time and time again, Senator. Despite Senator Kemp's constant interjections, we have tried. As an example of the good faith that we have shown in that respect, we are quite happy to support Senator Kernot's amendment for a program that will give greater opportunity for scrutiny of legislation—that is no problem at all. We have introduced new procedures; we have introduced new deadlines to ensure that the legislation is ready for introduction much earlier than it used to be when I first arrived here 10 years ago. If we did that, it would be a vast improvement on the way the place has operated for most of the last 90 years.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette's motion favours a buffer between the introduction of legislation and its actual passage. In line with that very principle, the government has been working towards ensuring that the non-budget legislation has its introduction in one sitting and its passage in the next. That is pretty much an ideal situation. It is an aim that any good government would want to achieve; it is a legitimate aim for the Senate to seek to achieve.

On 23 July, well in advance of this sitting, the government circulated a brief description of each bill as part of its global legislation program. That gives senators an idea of the substance of the legislation and some opportunity to consider it, to begin researching it and to ask whatever questions need to be asked well in advance of its introduction. Further, we have given undertakings to make briefings available on all bills to everyone. Some of us have been doing that for a very long time, anyway. The access to information currently available to senators for any piece of legislation is far greater than at any time in the chamber's history. That can be put down to two things: the actions of the chamber itself and the government's willingness to go along with a program that enhances and increases the opportunities for more knowledge of legislation before it hits the place.

The government has also tried to improve scrutiny by increasing the level of resources that are available to senators. That is a process that has been going on for quite some time. Senators have been offered extra staff. In many cases, that has been accepted; in some cases, it has not. But the main point is that the effort has been there to make sure that senators have the opportunity to examine, either through themselves or their staff—

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that offer made? I didn't hear it actually.
—There was an offer, as I understand it.
—To me?
—I do not know whether it was made to Senator Harradine. I only wish I had the opportunity to make Senator Harradine such an offer.
—What about us?
—Senator McKiernan has the opportunity of using my staff at any time—day or night. He is so popular with them that they would be more than happy to help him out.

—Back off then! Senator Chamarette might have had a careful look at an offer on staff. She had her own view on that, and that is fine. The government has even announced an intention to deliver the budget in June from next year onwards. That will give some unprecedented opportunities for the Senate. In future years, appropriation bills will be introduced obviously much earlier. When we get around to looking at—
—Just a second. I will get the sentence out and then I will listen to the interjection. When we then get around—
—Is it worth listening to?

—No, it probably is not, but I will try. When we get around to looking at an appropriate sitting pattern that is structured around that new time for the budget, then the opportunities for examination, especially of budget legislation, are far greater as of that moment than they have ever been. In the last few years, the government has taken step after step to enhance scrutiny, and we would like to see that continue.

PARA.TAB: All the time that that is going on, the government still has to be able to govern, and that is the crux of today's motion. It is that capacity, that ability to govern, that is now under threat. No matter how well intended, this motion will frustrate government, not enhance scrutiny. It is simply not possible for government legislation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your troops are unhappy.

—Which troops are unhappy? Look at ours: they are deliriously happy. Has anyone ever seen smiles bigger than these? They are far from being unhappy. They are very happy indeed. They are unhappy on Senator Kemp's side. As I understand it, the person he sits next to in this chamber has been very unhappy recently and has been only too willing to let that unhappiness show in interview after interview. As I was saying before I was rudely interrupted, it is just not possible for government legislation to be prepared under the timetable that this motion demands.

PARA.TAB: As I have already said, the government is confident—even though there are some difficulties about it—that half of its legislation will be in by 21 October anyway. That in itself puts pressure on those who have got responsibility for the drafting exercise. If we take that further and bring it in weeks in advance, then that pressure is unbearable and the possibility of error will be much stronger. A deadline of 29 October 1993, as this motion proposes, will not do anything to improve the quality of the legislation introduced.

The motion also seems to assume that the build-up of legislation towards the end of the sittings is in some way a problem caused by the government. That has certainly not been my experience over the course of the last decade. We take every opportunity and make every effort to get legislation in here as early as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute nonsense.

If those opposite want to avoid the build-up of that legislation, all I can say is that Senator Chamarette's motion will do nothing to help it because it does not address the delaying tactics that the opposition engage in at the end of every session. It does not even begin to attack the strategy to which I earlier referred—the strategy to frustrate and obstruct—that gets us into strife every time.

I believe that there is a further problem which cuts right across this motion. The motion has the necessary effect of the Senate imposing constraints on the business of the House of Representatives. TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the original motion put by Senator Chamarette and support the amendment put by my leader, Senator Kernot. In doing so, I would like to pick up on a few of the points that have been made in the debate so far.

PARA.TAB: First of all, it ill behoves Senator Robert Ray to accuse the Greens as to whether or not they have a mandate in relation to this particular question. In fact, the government, which now presumably has a mandate in relation to not raising taxes, moved before the last election to bring in legislated tax cuts which it has failed to do. I think it is not a particularly good argument on Senator Ray's part to raise the issue of mandates with respect to the Greens.

But equally I think Senator Alston accused the government of putting forward an alternative proposal that would have to be taken on faith. He said that he was not prepared to take the government on faith with respect to those proposals when Senator Kernot's amendment gives effect precisely to the undertakings which Senator Gareth Evans gave in this chamber this afternoon. So there is an opportunity for Senator Alston to check the bona fides of the government by supporting the amendment moved by Senator Kernot.

Indeed, the government is very much on the line. If that amendment is accepted, the government, as the amendment says, will have to produce by Monday, 30 August, a list of all bills which it intends to introduce in a particular session and to provide a brief description summary of the contents of those bills. It then must have 50 per cent of the total number of bills introduced in either the Senate or the House of Representatives by 21 October. So I think the government has in this instance shown its good faith with respect to those undertakings by saying that it will support the amendment.

In support of the position I take on this issue, I would simply point to the fact that although Senator Macklin introduced a cut-off motion all those years ago which seemed to work quite well for a number of sessions, I think everybody who has been in this chamber for a while is aware of the fact that increasingly it has been working less well. That is shown quite clearly by the table which was put before us earlier today in this debate.

Looking at that table, we see that in the 1972 budget 63 per cent of that session's bills were passed in the last four weeks; and that in the 1992 budget, a figure of 74 per cent were passed—not all that different. So if we look at the budget session of 1991, for instance, when only 44 per cent of those bills were passed in the last four weeks, we see that while the Macklin cut-off motion worked for a while and did seem to move legislation into the earlier part of the session, increasingly it has been frustrated. I would have to agree that the government has been frustrated substantially by the efforts of the opposition filibustering earlier in the session, particularly over the appropriation bills in the last session which caused the bank-up of legislation to occur later.

We want to put before the government a number of proposals which will address this whole problem in a much broader way. Let me, without too much cynicism, suggest that perhaps this government could save a great deal of money if it guillotined all bills through the House of Representatives. Matters in that chamber are decided simply on the numbers, bills could be dealt with in a minute or less, it could sit for a day and then its members could all go home. The one thing on which the Democrats and the opposition certainly agree is that this chamber works extremely well precisely because no party in this chamber has the numbers simply to ram legislation through. It is in this chamber where legislation is dealt with properly.

The issue of giving adequate time for legislation is an important one. We have established an excellent committee system which allows legislation, simply on the call of a single senator, to be sent off to a committee to be reviewed. As Senator Baume himself indicated earlier, legislation had been rammed through the House of Representatives, with no amendment being dealt with in this place over several months, and resulting in a number of amendments. In one case I dealt with, there were 87 amendments in a package of legislation; in another case Senator Lees dealt with, there were 106 amendments in another package of legislation. We in this chamber properly carry out the democratic function of this Parliament. Contrary to what Senator Robert Ray said, that function is not carried out in the other place because of the method of election.

In connection with the order in which legislation is introduced, everybody would be aware that we normally sit for a week or a fortnight longer than the House of Representatives because legislation is normally introduced first in the House of Representatives. Perhaps the House of Representatives could begin its sittings earlier than the Senate so that there would be some legislation available for us when we begin.

It is for those sorts of reasons that I believe the amendment which has been put up by Senator Kernot is a much better way of proceeding. We have an undertaking from the government that it will support that amendment; it will seek to meet the terms of that amendment. I simply give notice that that amendment is part of a much broader policy which needs to be looked at that will further reform the way in which legislation is dealt with in this chamber. In that way it will be properly reviewed, and properly amended when amendment is needed. Such a process will ensure that the very best legislation is moved and passed in this place for the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The problem needs to be addressed in a constructive way. Some government senators have indicated that they recognise the problem and are prepared to address it. Senator Faulkner has assured us that he intends to address it. I would urge all senators to do the same because of the difficulty the legislative program may present to those who are drafting legislation based on budget bills.

Senator Evans's second problem was that he felt that the fail-safe aspects of the motion, contained in paragraph (3), would not be adequate. He demonstrated quite a considerable lack of faith—in which he was joined by several of his colleagues—in the credibility of the opposition. I believe that the credibility of the opposition will be at stake if it maintains an oppositional stance after having so clearly stated its intentions in support of this motion. I would much rather give opposition members the benefit of the doubt and allow them to show that to the community than to make allegations against them ahead of time.

Thirdly, Senator Evans stated that for the Senate to seek to directly determine how the House of Representatives acts is unconscionable and direct proscription. That is nonsense. If it were true, it should apply much more to the amendment that was put forward by the Australian Democrats, for which the Government signified its support. Throughout that amendment there were references to how the House of Representatives should maintain its approach to the legislation, whereas my motion simply refers to the way the Senate will conduct itself. It allows the option of being totally open about how the House of Representatives will respond. I feel that is perfectly appropriate.

I appreciated the incongruity, the paradox, that was presented by the Greens both being `extraordinarily naive' and `terribly misguided'—linked in many ways with all sorts of qualities. Whatever our motives are, a positive solution can be such providing we exercise our political will and work towards it. We have an opportunity to do that with this motion.

If the Government acceded to the requests within this motion, all of us in the chamber would have much less to filibuster about. We would have more notice of, and more genuine issues to raise in regard to, the legislation than to be bothered with any filibustering, which I must confess I have done on occasions. I did it in most notable form in relation to the Migration Amendment Act—an immoral and scandalous piece of legislation which was pushed through parliament within one day, legislation which pre-empted an appeal to the High Court by the boat people at Port Hedland. So that is the primary motivation by which I came to look at the procedures of the Senate and tried to make some constructive responses.

As well as having less to filibuster about if this motion succeeded, there would be community credibility. If the government cooperates with this motion, and the opposition prevents it working in an effective manner, we are accountable to the community. That is essentially the accountability that we should be concerned about in our debate in this chamber. The House of Representatives should demonstrate more concern for accountability to the people, which the submission to the parliamentary process allows.

I acknowledge Senator Faulkner's attempt to deal with the program difficulties that the legislative program presents to all senators, but to the Greens in particular. I commend the government for giving us earlier notification of programs and assuring us of briefings. Those ministerial briefings have commenced. This full communication is very worthwhile. It shows the good faith of the government. It is an opportunity for a new era in the Senate, a chance for us to debate in a new way the legislation ahead of us.

We all know that there is a problem. Others who have far more experience than I have expressed it. This motion is an experiment. It may not be effective in achieving its goals. It will take all senators and all members of the House of Representatives to cooperate with the spirit of the motion to achieve those goals. If improvements are forthcoming I am more than willing to accept them. This issue transcends party politics. It is of concern to all members of parliament who value their responsibility to due parliamentary process.

I have looked at Senator Kernot's amendment. I would have given a critique of it, but we have already made that decision and so I will leave it out. I would like to talk about Senator Harradine's contribution. It was Senator Harradine who put forward for discussion the use of the word `urgent' and the way in which it could possibly lead to some problem. I would like to say why I put paragraph (3) in my motion.

Senator Faulkner quite correctly pointed out that it was his concern that `budget' and `urgent'—meaning crucial—legislation may be impeded by my motion. I took that from him with due sincerity and I tried to make allowances for it through my paragraph (3). However, my paragraph (3) does not actually state anything more than the obvious, which is that, by leave, at any point in any sittings material can be introduced for good reason, and it relies on the good faith of the Senate to pass that.

Paragraph (3) in my motion was, therefore, superfluous. I did not put it in, because it was superfluous, but when the motion began to receive publicity from Minister Beazley regarding what I considered to be disinformation that it might actually prevent some of the budget legislation getting through to the Senate, I placed it in so that any media who were looking at the motion would be in no doubt that that practice was available.
